greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Decimal expansion of reciprocal of fine-structure constant alpha.
comment: The fine-structure "constant" actually isn't a constant, it depends on the energy at which it is measured: Its value is known to approach 1/128 at interaction energies above 80 GeV. For other considerations, e.g., whether the value of the fine-structure constant differs by location and over time, see the Wikipedia article or other links. - _M. F. Hasler_, Oct 30 2013
reference: John Barrow, The Constants of Nature, 367 pp., Jonathan Cape, 2002.
K. R. Lang, Astrophysical Data: Planets and Stars, Springer-Verlag, NY, 1991.
Martin J. Rees, Just Six Numbers: the deep forces that shape the universe, Phoenix, 1999.
N. J. A. Sloane and Simon Plouffe, The Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences, Academic Press, 1995 (includes this sequence).
link: E. R. Cohen and B. N. Taylor, The 1986 adjustment of the fundamental physical constants, Rev. Modern Phys., 59 (1987), 1121-1148.
Morel, L., Yao, Z., Cladé, P. et al. Determination of the fine-structure constant with an accuracy of 81 parts per trillion. Nature 588, 61-65 (2020). doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2964-7
Robert P. Munafo, Notable Properties of Specific Numbers.
results.author: _N. J. A. Sloane_, _Mira Bernstein_
ext: Dropped the digits that could change with 1 standard error variation of the value provided by CODATA - _Andrey Zabolotskiy_, Dec 12 2020
